title: Boy banned from trampoline because of his prosthetic legs receives £2.5k in discrimination claim
text:
A 10-year-old boy who was banned from using a trampoline because of his prosthetic legs has received £2,500 after his family won a settlement for disability discrimination.

Zack Gordon, from County Down, was seven when staff at We Are Vertigo trampoline park in Newtownbreda, Belfast refused him access to their equipment on safety grounds.

This was despite him being given trampoline safety gear while watching an instructional video along with his friends, according to Zack's father, Patrick.

He declined the other activities offered to him as he wanted to stay with his friends playing on the trampolines.

His parents decided to sue the firm for disability discrimination with the help of the Equality Commission of Northern Ireland after the incident left their son “upset and sad”.

Mr Gordon said his son lost his lower legs when he was 14 months because of a congenital condition which meant his lower leg did not form properly in the womb.

But he insisted that his son's prosthetic legs, which are made of plastic-fibre glass with rubber feet, had never been a barrier to him taking part in sport activities.
